author: @CrissyUnfiltered
text: Amazing content Alex! I never thought of data analytics until I started my own YT channel. When I was younger I knew I always wanted to have a career ‚Äúhelping people‚Äù. I always looked at healthcare so that‚Äôs exactly what I did, I went into nursing and became a nurse. I have always been a curious person searching for the why behind everything. I love being a nurse but I feel that it is time for a change.   When I created my travel channel I just really enjoyed creating content, editing, creating scripts, monitoring the performance, etc. I started to research how to get into tech and started learning SQL not realizing I used similar skills before.  After days of research I‚Äôve become even more interested in creating projects based on data. Recently started the google data analyst cert and I‚Äôm loving it so far.   There is so much to learn and I‚Äôm still not sure how to even begin with tailoring my resume for a career change. I will continue to watch your channel because you seem very transparent and the info is very helpful.   Thank you so much! I‚Äôm looking to learn so much more from you! üòä

text: Hi Alex, you really are an inspiration. My cliff notes story is I had a kid young and never finished my bachelors but over time was able to at least finish my associates ( all though it is a complete mess of courses with no focus) I got a job about 10 years ago that was in a B2B call center. Small company. A couple years in I was helping with a project and the owner liked my excel skills and I was able to move into a position that cleaned, prepped and loaded data for projects. Over time I learned little things here and there with sql, some Marcos in excel to help automate some reports I did. I had a report that took hours I got down to about 15 minutes . üôÉ  So I have just been there since but I am trying to grow my skills because I feel like I just know small pieces of a bunch of different things. I have just felt stuck for the last few years. Your story inspires me to push and just dedicate the time to learn and do projects and make a portfolio. Because in the end, no one can take away your knowledge. And knowledge is power and opportunity.  Great video!

author: @ericfiumano4694
text: Hello Alex,  Thanks for all your content; believe, it's very concise and valuable to anybody.   I'd like to ask you (and everybody else who could help), some suggestions regarding how to move: Goals: - Work as Data Analyst (and maybe going on to something more Data science related, but that's to be thought) - Work remotely (I don't have any particular wish concerning the country. Remote cause I wanna move on an island :D ) - gettin paid more compared to now (who wouldn't :D)  My Background: - I'm 32yo, even if I don't have it written on my resume and people think I'm 8year younger  :D - 4y experience as Business Analyst (doing Functional analysis an testing) in banking field - knowledge of Excel, SQL and basics of Python, Tableau, ETL processes - Bachelor degree in Economics where I got enough quantitative knowledge (especially Stats) - Attended the Google Data Analytics 6 months course  - languages: proficiency in Eng, Italian native, some French and German, too.   Thoughts: I've tried some courses, in a way or in another, and I think that I'm tired to attend anything in which I always have to do the same basic things, since I think they won't get me anywhere.  I wonder if I should attend something that's more 'seriours' and tough, rather than a simple course...but still, what and taught by who?  It's then ok for me to pay 20/40‚Ç¨ a month for a course, even 1000/2000‚Ç¨ for a full course, but only if it really gives me a good boost.  Maybe I should gather self-taught experience workiung on Kaggle datasets and then try to apply to a newbie job, even part-time.  What would you think about getting into a low exp part-time job? Do you think I could ever be chosen?   Anything I would do now, is something I woulds start to do part-time, since still got a full-time job, even if I got plenty of spare-time because I'm not always full of tasks and I work remotely.   Then, would it have any sense to think to go on into Data science or would it take too much time wo master  I know it can seem pretty confusionary, but, working with data is something I truely prefer over Functional stuff but, since I had to start working, I took what the market offered me back then :).   So....Suggestion? Is there anybody else who got the same problem?  Thanks in advance  Eric F.

text: Pepper. Pepper. And Pepper.  It was like listening to a story which was my favourite past time as a kid. Your journey does inspire me to do better every day. I did finish the Google Analytics Data Analytics course 4 months back only to realise that I need to work a lot on my technical and data related skills before I can even think about working as a Data Analyst. After working for 15 plus years majorly into HR, it is both difficult and easy to shift to a data driven career path. Currently working on my visualisation skills. Need to work on SQL too. Will keep watching your videos for inspiration, help with my career path and of course for your stories.

I was debating getting a business degree (BBA) but it seems like I will learn more doing the bootcamp and applying than going back for another degree. Let me know what you think!

text: I have nothing but respect for you! Thank you for sharing all this valuable information. I am data analyst for the past 4 years. Got to know excel, power bi, sql - in my opinion intermediate to advanced‚Ä¶ however i am starting to see a trend in the data analytics job‚Ä¶ while 3-4 years back having these skills and tableau was amazing i don‚Äôt know why almost everywhere i see them + python and ML‚Ä¶  note i speak for data analyst job offerings, not data science ones. I know it is good to have more and more technical skills but at some point programming is not for everyone‚Ä¶ not to mention that I really don‚Äôt have math background. Understanding statistics doesn‚Äôt mean we can run ML models‚Ä¶ it is getting a bit frustrating‚Ä¶ or at least i hope some HRs are really using buzz words‚Ä¶ how do you see a person if you have to hire today? What skills would you value more?

author: @estefanyfernandez1800
text: Hi Alex, I really like your content and how is easy to relate to your stories. My story is a little different but similar in the sense that I‚Äôve grown little by little to where I am. I have a bachelors degree in Engineering but from a foreign country. Coming to the US I had a lot of roadblocks starting by the language, no connections, unknown university and so. 4 years ago i had to start from the ground, I cleaned houses at $10/hour because I needed the money, started my way by an internship in procurement, after that got a job as a buyer, had a break for maternity, started again as an analyst 1.5 years ago and proudly landed my first Senior Analyst job earning almost $100k, something that I would never never imagine. If someone reads this and needs motivation, I would just say never give up, your current situation doesn‚Äôt define your future, is your willingness to grow! Best wishes in this new chapter of your life!!!

author: @peterM20
text: it is like my Data Analyst career is following Alex's track step by step. starting in Feb 2017 as a data analyst that was paying me $56k, I quit after 6 months because of a toxic Manager. struggled to find the next job in a different city and I became a personal trainer as I continue to learn analytic tools. finally found another one in May 2019.. that was $57k a year.  I left in June 2022 for a Fortune 200 company paying me $71k annually, and Last week was my last time with them as I got another offer that is paying me $105k and still remote. my plan is to stay with them for the next three years and if there is not improved promotion, I will bounce for something better but likely management.
